Wood is readily available in large volumes at low cost, and our most widely used biological material for load-bearing structures. There is also an established industrial infrastructure for harvesting and processing of trees into wood in forms such as wooden boards and veneers. From this advantageous position, wood can be further developed into a nanostructured multifunctional
material with vastly expanded application areas by modification and functionalization treatments.
Wood modification is a commonly used term, which with a few exceptions (heat treatment and related methods) implies that the porosity of the native wood structure is exploited. Wood modification has been very successful in terms of industrial applications and cost efficiency. Examples include impregnation by inorganic salts, resin impregnation, chemical cell wall modification, various coating approaches for functions such as UV-protection, moisture barrier, antifungal, or hydrophobicity and inorganics modification for fire-retardancy purposes.[6–9] The main focal points of wood modification research in the last 100 years have been to address outdoor durability and the hydrophilic nature of wood, which leads to swelling and shrinking under changes in relative humidity. In these fields, substantial wood property improvements could be reached and commercialized, such as acetylation of wood, where swelling and shrinkage are significantly reduced accompanied by strongly improved durability.[7] Such treatments are, however, applied in order to make wood inert rather than adding additional functionality, and modifications are carried out with rather little nanostructural control.
In recent years, research in wood nanotechnology toward new material concepts has become a rapidly emerging field. The term “wood nanotechnology” is perhaps primarily associated with research on the extraction and use of nanocellulose or lignin for new materials.[10,11] However, it also includes technologies applied to bulk wood materials. There are, for instance, already commercialized technologies for wood preservation using nanoparticles in the form of copper carbonate.[8] Although, one may argue that copper carbonate was not originally designed to function at nanoscale, this example provides strong arguments for the large-scale feasibility of wood nanotechnology.
In the present Progress Report, the term wood nanotechnology includes evolving technologies for advanced wood functionalization, where molecular and nanoscale features and pore space of the wood cell wall and the inner lumen surface area are targeted. Thereby, the functionalization takes place in confined
It is a challenging task to realize the vision of hierarchically structured nanomaterials for large-scale applications. Herein, the biomaterial wood as a large-scale biotemplate for functionalization at multiple scales is discussed, to provide an increased property range to this renewable and CO2-storing bioresource, which is available at low cost and in large quantities. The Progress Report reviews the emerging field of functional wood materials in view of the specific features of the structural template and novel nanotechnological approaches for the development of wood–polymer composites and wood–mineral hybrids for advanced property profiles and new functions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
One of the great challenges in materials science and engineering is the fabrication of functional materials with high nanostructural control in bottom-up approaches, which reach application-relevant dimensions. Up to dimensions in the range of centimeters, there has been tremendous progress in fabrication methods based on self-assembly processes by addressing the basic mechanisms and underlying principles.[1] As an example, man-made nanocrystals can be assembled to superlattice structures[2] and also, solid free-forming methods offer promise, for example in scaffold engineering.[3] However, these concepts have yet to demonstrate feasibility for use in large-scale structural applications, as it is a remaining challenge to produce macroscopic load-bearing materials with multiple levels of structural hierarchy, and in the short term, it will be very demanding to realize this vision.
The unique characteristics of wood, a biobased, renewable and mechanically robust scaffold with hierarchical structure, can make it possible to overcome some of these shortcomings. Wood with its large inner surface (300 m2 g−1 for swollen cell walls)[4] is highly suitable for nanotechnological processes via biotemplating or outer and inner surface

space at different length scales, and these porous regions can be deliberately utilized to fine-tune synthesis processes and reach improved and novel properties arising from nanostructural tailoring. Noteworthy, this emerging research field is still in an exploratory state and needs further efforts on process control and simplification to reach the level of engineering materials applications.
In order to introduce the underlying concept, we first discuss the basic principles of how large-scale load-bearing structures in nature are “designed.” These insights may serve as a source of bioinspiration. By use of the structural and mechanical property profile of wood and its internal multiscale porosity, not only can both the nano- and microscale structures be readily functionalized, but it is also possible to upscale technologies for large structural applications. Examples of simple functionalization schemes include attachment of organic molecules to internal surfaces for the purpose of adding new chemical and physical characteristics. In these new approaches toward specifically targeted function/property goals, the objective is full nanostructural control of the complex hierarchical wood structure. The present report emphasizes functional materials, where for example, magnetic, self-cleaning, conducting, or transparency functions are combined with the structural characteristics of wood scaffolds. The new material concepts and methodologies have tremendous potential for new applications of wood- and cellulose-derived materials contributing to a sustainable bioeconomy as there are new opportunities for wood in view of its renewable nature, ease of processing, favorable energy balance, and small contribution to the carbon footprint.
For the material concepts, we emphasize “Functional Wood Materials” rather than “Biotemplates,” which typically refer to inorganic porous materials fabricated by removal of the biological template.[12] The term functional wood materials refers to polymeric composites or hybrids where the wood or the cellulose tissue is preserved in the final material. This includes structural anisotropy and hierarchy, although this scaffold is modified with inorganic or organic/polymeric compounds. Hence, templating approaches for wood- or cellulose-derived ceramics, wood carbonization or the broad field of nanocellulose functionalization are not covered in this Progress Report and the interested reader is referred elsewhere.[5,13,14]

sections.heading: 2. Design Principles in Nature for Large-Scale Load-Bearing Structures
sections.text:
It would be of great practical value if we could extend the current range of material properties and functions, by assembling man-made or biobased building blocks to sophisticated multiscale composites inspired by nature. In nature, large-scale load-bearing structures have evolved successfully, such as trees and animal skeletons. Both examples show a multitude of functions based on complex hierarchical structures.[15–17] Although structural hierarchy is an obvious consequence of biosynthesis mechanisms in multicellular organisms, this structural arrangement also provides functional advantages. The bone material consists of hydroxyapatite nanoparticles in a matrix of collagen and other proteins,[18] but also contains nerves and is structured at larger scales for purposes such as blood supply,
cell regeneration, and mechanical function. Plant cell walls are sculptured from molecular to microscale and contain strong cellulose microfibrils in hydrated biopolymer matrices.[19–21] This scale is important for repair and remodeling in plants, and the modular multicellular organization makes it possible for the organism to adapt to environmental changes. For larger scale plant structures, shape and tissue organization combine mechanical function with hydraulic transport.[22]
A most significant characteristic of load-bearing materials in nature is that the tissue is itself a well-organized composite material at nanoscale, and this structural principle has widely inspired biomimetic materials research.[23] In bone or nacre the bioinspiration derives from a concerted chemical composition and specific structural organization at different length scales, which is aspired for technical composites.[17,24–26] As mentioned above, hierarchical structuring facilitates multifunctional properties, but it is perhaps best understood in the context of mechanical performance.[18,27] Properties such as toughness, which rely on complex deformation mechanisms, receive

Another particular feature of biological materials of interest for the fabrication of engineering materials is a high energy efficiency in processing and materials use, including its recycling. Biological organisms only use a few simple building blocks, a small amount of rather lightweight and strong elements and are able to assemble and organize them in waterbased processes at ambient temperatures.[17,18] The composites and hybrid materials synthesized from these energy saving conditions are highly sophisticated, due to the control of interface properties between material phases and hierarchical structuring.[17,23] Furthermore, biological systems with high potential as sources for bioinspiration are often rather simple organisms, which do not rely on highly complex nerve systems, so the functionality is often directly embedded in the material. One example is spiders, which have flow and vibration sensors incorporated in their legs.[29] Analogous systems can be found in plants. In the Venus fly trap, the leaves of the plant rapidly fold when the prey comes in contact with the sensory hairs on the inner surfaces of the leaf, resulting in an autonomous folding reaction.[30] Remarkably, even dead tissues and organs like pine cones or awns are able to conduct directed motion based on passive response to changes in relative humidity.[31] Hence sensors and actuators are implemented in the material itself, and the functionality at the nanoscale is transferred to macroscopic effects by a sophisticated hierarchical structure. Embedded functionalities mean that the living plant requires no additional physiological control in order to respond to an environmental stimulus. These biological systems are in this respect interesting models for functional engineering materials, and may provide new concepts stimulating new research as well as product development.

sections.heading: 3. Wood as a Biomaterial
sections.text:
Trees are known for exceptional longevity and durability with some individuals persisting for more than 6000 years. Trees are also prime examples of nature's ability to build very large hierarchical structures by molecular-, nano-, and microscale processing. Trees can grow taller than 100 m and can accumulate a stem volume of almost 1500 cubic meters. Wood is the product of a sensing and adapting organism, which is highly successful in competing with other plants, and the longevity is a result of a highly energy-efficient system. The cambium layer between the bark and the wood is the main productive unit of the stem. Wood is formed inwards from the cambium and bark outwards. The major part of wood cells (up to 95%) die at the end of their differentiation and synthesis process, and in the so-called heartwood at the center of the trunk of many trees there are no living cells.[32–34] Hence, in the massive stem of the living tree only a small fraction of cells have an active metabolism, the rest is a dead, passive support structure. This strategy is highly energy efficient and economical for the organism.
An important feature of wood, which can be utilized for functionalization treatments, is its sophisticated hierarchical
structure. Different structural levels can be defined,[15,35] starting from the nanoscale assembly of the cell wall biomacromolecules. The next higher level is characterized by the cell wall organization in terms of cell wall layers with different structural and chemical composition. At the microscale the individual cell types with different sizes, shapes, and functions, such as fibers, tracheids, or vessels form the wood tissues. At the macroscale, the assembly of these tissues constitutes the solid wood body.
Utilizing specific features of this evolutionary optimized structure and making use of the anatomical diversity of different wood species for targeted nanotechnological treatments in a topdown approach results in biobased and bioinspired materials. These materials are conceptually very different from materials that are based on classical wood modification treatments or that are produced in bioinspired bottom-up assembly processes.
A key element of the natural “biomaterial fabrication” is the sophisticated self-assembly process for making the cell walls.[15,19] The wood cell walls have very high stiffness and strength and the main biological building blocks to produce these exceptional fiber-reinforced nanocomposites are three biopolymers, namely cellulose, hemicelluloses, and lignin. Cellulose fibrils, with a diameter of around 3 nm, are produced by cellulose synthase complexes, and extruded to the cell wall in a collective manner.[19] In a self-assembly process at ambient temperature and pressure, the fibrils are interlinked with hemicelluloses and lignin, which form the surrounding matrix and act as a hydrogel.[19,36] A key feature of this biosynthesis processes is the control of cellulose fibril orientation in the cell wall by the cell in the fibril spinning process.[37] This is used to fine-tune the mechanical properties of the cell walls and allows for material adaptation in the growth process, even adapting to externally imposed deformation.[38]
The structural optimization of wood at its microscale is predominately toward water transport and mechanical stability. Both are essential requirements, and result from the principle of “survival of the fittest” where trees compete with other plants for light and photosynthesis. Hence, the main functions of the wood body in the living tree are to conduct water from the roots to the crown and to assure mechanical stability of the long and slender stem by resisting mainly bending loads due to wind.[39] In terms of the optimization of wood anatomy, these two functions have been counteractive drivers of structural adaptation. This has contributed to the development of the complex hierarchical wood structure with a cell and tissue specific allocation of tasks.[15,22] The efficient water transport is based on a highly porous unidirectional tubular structure, resulting from the death of cells after differentiation accompanied by the disintegration of the protoplast.[40] Mechanical stability is achieved by compact cell walls and a minimization of the cross-sectional cell lumen pore area. During evolution, trees have achieved an astonishing optimization of the wood structure in forming earlywood and latewood in conifers with severe density differences. Earlywood consists of axially oriented cells (tracheids) with thin walls and wide lumina, which facilitates water transport, whereas thick-walled cells with narrow lumina form the latewood for mechanical support. From the evolutionary perspective, the younger hardwood trees are even further optimized, with more complex vessels and fibers in the structure. This functional optimization of dead plant material for the benefit of the

living organism has resulted in a very rigid but porous structure. In the living tree, this porous structure is filled by water. Before we use wood as a structural material, this water is removed. It is then possible to profit from the evolutionary optimization, by using a porous, lightweight material of high mechanical performance for engineering applications. Wood competes remarkably well with other materials, when comparison is made on the basis of specific strength and modulus.[41] Since tree stems are optimized to withstand bending due to wind loads, this loading case is particularly favorable and wood outperforms many other engineering materials used in construction.[42]
Bioinspiration can also be gained from the biosynthesis processes in trees, and this may be helpful for new processing concepts. This is particularly important for processing where some nanostructural control is exercised, since synthetic methods are still fairly primitive in comparison with biological synthesis. One example is natural modification processes of the wood cell wall, where reconstruction can take place by insertion of additional molecular components. In the first phase of differentiation of a wood cell, the cell wall is formed without lignin. Lignin molecules are inserted into the porous and aqueous cellulose–hemicellulose network in a subsequent step. This takes place by means of small precursor units and lignin polymerization in the final cell formation step to form a compact cell wall composite.[43,44] The lignification step can be interpreted as a natural modification process and the underlying mechanisms may inspire synthetic nanotechnology approaches where wood cell walls are subjected to biofunctionalization. One important question is how the more hydrophobic lignin molecules can diffuse into the hydrophilic environment of the aqueous cellulose–hemicellulose network. Recent findings by Dupree and co-workers on the decoration of cellulose fibrils by xylans can provide significant hints. They suggest that the hydrophilic regions of the cellulose fibrils are coated by xylans, and that hydrophobic acetyl groups of the xylans point outwards to face the porous matrix region between the cellulose fibrils.[45]
A further physiological process of particular interest for functionalization of the lignified cell wall is the so-called heartwood formation. It takes place in the inner part of the tree stem and can result in an increased durability of the wood, as is the case for oak, black locust, or teak. In this process, trees modify lignified wood cell walls of the dead cells by insertion of extractives such as phenols.[33,46] These chemical compounds are synthesized by the until then living parenchyma cells (mainly present in the wood rays). Extractives are excreted into the surrounding tissue of dead fibers, tracheids, or vessels. Although the physiological processes and the chemical composition of the compounds have been studied in great detail,[34,47] there are still open questions regarding the basic mechanisms of the cell wall modification process during heartwood formation. One relates to the modification pathways into the cell walls, which could be via the empty lumina of the dead cells, but also via the middle lamella. A better understanding of the underlying principles and diffusion pathways may prove critical to improve functionalization treatments of wood. Another question concerns the mechanisms which facilitate transport of hydrophobic compounds into the cell wall and long-term embedding. Since natural cell wall modifications happen in water and at ambient temperature, they represent a great source of bioinspiration for wood nanotechnology.
We may eventually learn how to integrate a second material phase into the wood structure, using a green process.
Wood takes a special position in the context of bioinspired materials research. It serves both as a biological model for man-made materials with interesting structures, but is also already widely used as an engineering material. Wood materials with new functionalities can therefore be quickly transferred to large-scale technical applications. For instance, large-scale wood processing units may be readily adapted for wood nanomaterials. However, service conditions are very different for the biological wood material and the functional wood materials in engineering applications. Wood in the tree is always in wet condition and biologically adapted to this state. It is protected from the environment by the bark, which eliminates influences of relative humidity changes and impedes fungal attack.[48] Furthermore, in many trees, the bark functions as a protection against fire[49] and/or rock fall.
In engineering wood materials, the moisture content instead depends on the relative humidity of the environment. High humidity facilitates fungal decay and humidity changes induce swelling and shrinkage. Another factor for processing of “engineering wood” relates to changes in liquid permeability. In living softwood trees, water transport takes place from cell to cell (tracheids) via holes in the cell wall, so-called bordered pits. However, in dried wood, many water flow channels have been blocked, since the bordered pits are closed as a reaction to air intrusion. The permeability is decreased, impeding small distance fluid transport. This makes all modification and functionalization treatments more challenging, and these are therefore typically carried out using vacuum or high pressure treatments.[50]

sections.heading: 4. Unique Opportunities in Using the Hierarchical Structured Wood Scaffold
sections.text:
By using the hierarchical structure of wood (Figure 1) as scaffold subjected to advanced functionalization schemes, we may be able to bypass research and development efforts on assembly
Adv. Mater. 2018, 30, 1704285
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1704285 (5 of 15)
processes and realize new types of functional wood materials. Although bottom-up procedures have been highly successful to realize nanostructured materials, the tasks in the form of large, load-bearing structures are challenging. Figure 2 illustrates the challenges in terms of the number of scales we need to control in order to match the sophistication of biological structures, such as wood.
The well-concerted combination of structural and functional characteristics at different levels of structural hierarchy are important in the use of wood as a scaffold. The scaffold should feature preserved cellulose fibril network and nanoscale porosity. Processes for wood functionalization can then be designed with the internal multiscale porosity as a starting point. There are pore sizes at two different length scales with 10 µm scale lumen porosity, as well as molecular and nanoscale porosity in the cell wall. Analogous to functional inorganics,[51] solid surfaces can be provided with new functionalities.
One processing goal of particular scientific interest is full nanostructural control of the functionalized material, for an extended range of properties. Methods such as layer by layer (LbL) deposition, inorganic nanoparticle precipitation, advanced polymerization and polymer grafting methods, surface functionalization, mineralization, or metallization can be readily applied to wood scaffolds. For instance, in biomineralization processes, such as those in bone or sea sponges, analogous functionalization takes place in the form of mineralization in prearranged biological scaffolds. The scaffolds provide both the hierarchical structure and the local compartmentalization for the material transformation.[25] Likewise the inherent structural wood features can be utilized. This includes liquid conduction, load-bearing functions (strength, stiffness, and toughness at low density), and property anisotropy.
At the nanostructural level, the main target for functionalization treatments is the macromolecular composite of the wood cell wall. In the living tree, the cell walls of wood contain ≈30% of water and can therefore be viewed as a hydrogel, where the water molecules can be replaced by other compounds. It has been shown by AFM studies that the cellulose fibrils of 3 nm diameter form larger so-called cellulose aggregates (20–30 nm),[21] which are hardly accessible for agents to be embedded. However, the surrounding matrix consisting of hemicelluloses and lignin is nanoporous, which allows for functionalization treatments. Thereby, specific scaffold features such as the preferred nanocellulose fibril orientation pattern in the cell walls can be utilized. In the processed material, the load-bearing properties of wood are then combined with new features. Nanostructured polymer composites of wood–polymer, or wood/inorganic hybrids can be prepared in such a way that new inorganic or organic/polymeric phases are present at predesigned locations, such as inside the wood cell wall, as coatings of the lumen wall, or filling the lumen space.
A further approach that has gained increasing attention is the delignification of wood cell walls, while retaining the wood macrostructure.[52] Structure-preserving delignification followed by polymer impregnation was used as a preparation method for light microscopy studies[53] and later facilitated the preparation of wood templated ceramics down to the nanoscale of the wood cell wall.[13,54] Yano and co-workers[55] prepared delignified wood scaffolds for the purpose of maximizing the mechanical properties of wood-PF (phenol formaldehyde resin) composites. Li et al.[56] and Zhu et al.[57] have since used it for the purpose of increasing the cell wall nanoporosity for other types of scaffold functionalization. The advantage of delignified wood scaffolds is that the original wood structure with its overall morphology and cellular structure is preserved, while the cell wall porosity is vastly increased. The obvious challenge is that the mechanical robustness of the wood scaffold is compromised, so that handling without structural damage may be more difficult. Recently, great progress in the field was made by fabrication of transparent wood,[53,56] which will be discussed in more detail in the following chapter. Figure 3 illustrates the cell wall scaffolds, which can be utilized for biofunctionalization treatments, referring to the biological role models for processing in terms of cell wall lignification and heartwood formation.
Furthermore, one cannot only benefit from the wood structure at the cell wall level but also from the microscale porosity at cell and tissue scale (see Figure 1). This scale provides short diffusion distances during fabrication and can be used to dictate and fine-tune property profiles and utilize the anisotropic and hierarchical nature of wood. In particular, at this microscale it is possible to profit from the natural diversity provided by nature and tailor toward functionality by selection of species. While the variation at the wood cell wall level is relatively minor (e.g., density, fiber composite structure), there is a huge variety of cell and tissue characteristics among species. Depending on the targeted functionality of the final wood material, the most suited structural features can be selected. Thereby, the most obvious characteristic is density with a range from ≈100 kg m−3 for species like balsa to heavy weight species ≈1200 kg m−3

(e.g., pockwood). Furthermore, the structural organization of cells can be used as a criterion, when the tree species for the wood scaffold is selected. Softwoods with a tissue structure of earlywood and latewood layers provide a microstructural pattern of alternating bands of different strength and liquid conductivity. This is for instance particularly pronounced in larch wood. Since the tracheids are individual units, they can be characterized as microcompartments in terms of functionalization. This can be an advantage since they can serve as microreaction
containers. However, this is also a challenge for a functionalization scheme that requires the embedding of a continuous phase, as in the case of electrical conductivity. Here, a simple decoration of the inner lumen surface with a conductive material is not sufficient as the unmodified wood cell walls act as an electrical insulator. More sophisticated functionalization treatments are therefore required, with more nanostructural control.[52]
Hardwood species can be selected for functionalization on the basis of the length, diameter, quantity, and distribution of the liquid conducting vessels. For these elements, the principle of individual cells as basic structural units is not always relevant for material functions. For liquid transport, hundreds to thousands of cells cooperatively form one large vessel, since the end of each cell has been removed (the transverse wall). This is analogous to a long water transport pipe, which is built by connecting several pipe elements. The vast diversity of structural features of vessels in different tree species can be highly beneficial when the wood scaffold is functionalized to serve as flow-through elements for filter or membrane applications.[58] Ring-porous species like oak or ash possess earlywood vessels with diameters of up to 500 µm and of several meters in length. This could potentially be utilized for applications where high flow rate is important. Diffuse-porous species such as maple, beech, or poplar have much more uniform and homogenously distributed vessels of smaller dia meter, which may serve after specific functionalization for membrane technologies. On the basis of selected representative examples, Figure 4 illustrates the tissue diversity among different species.
5. Functional Materials Derived from Wood Scaffolds
Wood offers unique opportunities for further chemical and physical functionalization toward a specific target. Wood nanoscience for functional materials can exploit the nanoporosity of the cell wall itself, and also increase cell wall nanoporosity by chem-
ical pretreatment methods such as delignification schemes. The nanoporous cellulosic scaffold can be functionalized in many different ways. These include attachment of organic molecules to the internal surfaces of the scaffold, filling with functional polymers, precipitation of inorganic nanoparticles in the pore space etc. These molecular tailoring activities have different scope from approaches developed during 1960s and onwards, which focused on the solution of dimensional stability and preservation problems through empirical approaches. sections.heading: 5.1. Polymer Functionalization
sections.text:
Previous research on wood–polymer composites is dominated by the practical need to solve moisture stability problems. In addition, this work is often constrained by the need for low-cost production required for “bulk materials” for the building sector. New efforts on polymer functionalization are more exploratory in nature and combine wood science with chemistry and chemical engineering toward synthesis of new wood–polymer nanostructures, generation of new material concepts and new preparation methods. The location of the polymer phase is of obvious importance to properties and functions of the material. A scheme of a selection of recent modification protocols is presented in Figure 5.
The inner cell wall surface can be subjected to surface modification (cell wall–lumen interface), the cell wall can be modified (cell wall modification), and the lumen can be filled with a polymer (lumen filling). An important progress ingredient is the development of new nanoscale techniques for
characterization of the modified wood cell wall. Although transmission electron microscopy has been around for a long time, this technique requires cumbersome specimen preparation and does not always provide sufficient contrast between different polymers, unless specific markers are used. Raman microscopy is a simpler and very powerful technique for mapping polymer distribution in the cell wall. The principles for the method have been described elsewhere.[60,61] These characterization methods are essential in order to eventually achieve nanostructural control of the polymer distribution in functionalized wood.
Nanostructural control implies that we can control the location and distribution of the polymer phases. This is relevant for advanced functional wood–polymer composites intended for energy storage (electrical conductivity), water purification, or in responsive systems where material properties are altered due to changes in pH, temperature, relative humidity, light, or application of external fields (magnetic, electrical etc.). In terms of polymer preparation, controlled polymerization methods are important for synthesis of well-defined polymers such as block copolymers or homopolymers of controlled molar mass. “Grafting from” approaches[62] are of particular interest in the context of wood scaffolds. Atom transfer radical polymerization, reversible addition–fragmentation chain transfer polymerization and ring opening polymerization can all be grafted from
Adv. Mater. 2018, 30, 1704285
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1704285 (8 of 15)
surfaces for the purpose of functionalization.[63] Surface-initiated polymerization schemes (SI-ATRP, SI-RAFT, SI-ROP) can all be used for wood modification. In an early attempt, a free radical initiator was attached to hydroxyl groups inside the cell wall.[64] Styrene was brought into the cell wall and polymerized using free-radical polymerization. The resulting wood–polymer composite showed hydrophobic characteristics. In another study,[61] the cell wall interior was functionalized by double bonds and then styrene monomers were brought inside and poly merized. The distribution of the polymer could then be controlled through the distribution of the initiating species. Classical freeradical polymerization can also be used for grafting by attachment of initiators inside the wood scaffold. An example of how this could lead to novel wood functionalization is the insertion of pH-responsive polymers. Poly(methacrylic acid) (PMA) polyelectrolyte grafting was compared with another polyelectrolyte, poly(2-dimethylamino)ethyl methacrylate) (PDMAEMA).[64] Both were polymerized inside the cell wall. PMA-modified wood sorbed more water under basic conditions, whereas the PDMAEMA composite sorbed more under acidic conditions. The functional behavior of the grafted polymers is manifested also in modified wood. Another advantage of covalent grafting is of course that the polymers will stay inside the wood structure even if the material is completely immersed in water.
An important area for functional composites is conducting materials. Electrical conductivity is relevant for solar cells, batteries, supercapacitors, and electrochromic devices. Cost-effective energy generation and storage are important focus areas, and biobased materials of low cost do indeed have potential for largescale applications. Trey et al.[65] successfully polymerized aniline in birch veneer and reported high conductivity due to polyaniline in the lumen space. For electrically conducting materials, the anisotropic structure of wood provides specific advantages in
terms of directional properties. Lv et al. published a similar study using polypyrrole.[66] They noted the mechanical flexibility of the materials and suggested use as conducting support structures for electronics applications. Other functional advantages included improved fire retardancy and reduced decay sensitivity.[67]

sections.heading: 5.2. Wood–Mineral and Wood–Metal Hybrids
sections.text:
Historically, both wood preservation[68] and fire retardancy treatments[69] are often based on inorganics. Nanostructured organic–inorganic wood hybrids may, however, offer new possibilities both scientifically and in terms of industrial potential. An important research goal is therefore to be able to control the nanoscale distribution of inorganic matter in wood tissue, and to understand mechanisms for nanoparticle effects on wood properties. Figure 6 exemplarily illustrates different wood–mineral hybrids and the different distribution patterns in the wood structure, in dependence of the chosen mineral component and the functionalization treatment.
Other organic–inorganic hybrids are often based on nanostructured and porous inorganic scaffolds functionalized by organic molecules. These molecules are attached to the internal surfaces of the porous scaffold.[51] Wood scaffolds offer new possibilities as they consist of a structural material of high stiffness and toughness. The specific surface area can probably also be very high, since wood nanocellulose aerogels can reach 500–600 m2 g−1.[73] One may consider wood as low cost, nanostructured substrate for advanced hybrid applications such as catalyst supports, sorption and purification of liquids, electrodes, insulating materials and photonic materials. Inclusion of inorganic nanoparticles is another route, which may provide additional possibilities beyond existing hybrids.[52]

Silanes are versatile compounds for wood modification, since there is a large variety of compounds and chemical functionalities available. Tetraalkoxy silane treatment can improve dimensional stability and fire retardancy of wood, and reactions inside the cell wall can be readily induced.[74] Silane methodologies are based on monomer or oligomeric diffusion into the wood cell wall.[75] An advantage is that the solution can readily impregnate the cell wall, although smaller molecules result in better performance of the functionalized structure.
Magnetic function is a good example of what can be achieved by inorganic particle precipitation. In the first attempt for cellulosic materials, Marchessault et al. precipitated magnetic nanoparticles inside discrete wood fibers.[76] Olsson et al. then formed cobalt ferrite nanoparticles inside a cellulose nanofibril hydrogel.[77] Recently, Merk et al.[71] successfully prepared magnetic wood by a related precipitation approach. X-ray diffraction and Raman analyses showed the formation of multidomain ferrite particles inside the wood structure, decorating the inside of the lumen walls in an ordered fashion. In terms of structural control, this is in contrast to random filling of lumen space typical for conventional chromated copper arsenate (CCA)impregnated wood. This magnetic wood study shows the specific impact of the anisotropy of the wood structure on magnetic properties of the hybrid material. Magnetization occurred predominantly along the axial direction, in parallel with the direction of wood tracheids and vessels. As a result wood structures can be manipulated by magnetic fields, for potential use in actuator applications or as magnetic switches. Trey et al. later showed that magnetic nanoparticles could also be precipitated inside the wood cell wall.[78]
For many applications, engineering wood structures need fire retardancy as one of the functionalities. The need for “green” technologies for treatment methods for fire retardant
wood is apparent, due to toxicity concerns with halogens, phosphates, sulfates, and related compounds. Recently, clay platelets were used to modify delignified wood for this purpose. Exfoliated nanoplatelets suspended in water diffused into the submicron pore space of the cell wall itself, and fire retardancy was improved.[79] Calcium carbonate is also of interest as a more environmentally friendly alternative to tackle wood flammability.[80] It is an important component in crustaceans and mollusk shells due to the availability of calcium in the sea. The exoskeleton in crustaceans is essentially a composite composed of hard calcium carbonate particles in a softer matrix of chitin fibrils and proteins.[81] The precipitation and growth mechanisms during biosynthesis are relevant for bioinspired materials. Also, the tailoring of hardness, stiffness, and strength in organisms through functional gradients in terms of particle type and content can inspire man-made materials. There are several studies where CaCO3 has been used to chemically modify the internal structure of wood.[82] More advanced approaches are using ionized surface groups of cellulose[83] or other carbohydrates[84] in order to nucleate crystallization of CaCO3. One challenge is to carry out modification also in the bulk of the wood material. In the context of nanoscience, it is also desirable to nucleate CaCO3 particle formation inside the wood cell wall rather than in lumen space. Finally, bioinspired approaches aiming for green technologies should preferable be carried out under ambient conditions and in water solution.
In a recent study, synthetic calcification of wood cell walls was carried out, meeting many of the mentioned criteria.[80] In biological mineralization processes, amorphous calcium carbonate (ACC) is in a transient phase, and stabilized by ions, biological polymers, or proteins.[85] All precursors are present in solution in this procedure, and they react to form ACC upon a given stimulus. Calcium carbonate is indeed formed inside the structure, and predominantly in the cell walls. The original wood porosity is therefore largely retained. Mass gains as high as 20% can be reached. The total heat release rate and peak heat release rate, measured by pyrolysis combustion flow calorimetry, are reduced to about one third of the values for unmodified wood.[80] This illustrates the potential of bioinspired mineralization approaches for wood modification and functionalization using scalable nanotechnology.

sections.heading: 5.3. Transparent Wood
sections.text:
Recent research on wood composites modified to become transparent (transparent wood, TW) has attracted attention from both researchers and industrial companies. It is an example where nanotechnology can result in unexpected material concepts, based on selection of material components and design of the material structure. TW was first prepared for wood morphology studies.[53] Li et al. then discussed the possibilities in engineering applications,[86] and reported physical properties. After this, many studies have considered applications primarily for buildings, solar cells, and in photonics.[57,87–92] In Li et al,[86] it was pointed out that transparent wood also has the advantage of low thermal conductivity through-the-thickness.
A first requirement for transparency is that light absorption from chemical groups is removed. Light scattering originates from air–tissue interfaces and possibly from cell wall porosity. The current approach to reduce scattering includes delignification of the wood scaffold and polymer impregnation. The refractive index of the polymer needs to match the wood scaffold.[53] It was recently demonstrated that bleaching (limited
lignin removal) rather than delignification has practical advantages, and the wood scaffold also shows better mechanical properties.[93]
Transparent wood composites can be used in architecture as load-bearing panels with unusual optical features, and favorable light transmission properties for energy-saving and increased daylight penetration. TW can also be viewed as a starting material for further functionalization. For instance, lumen space, as well as the interior of the cell wall, can be impregnated with liquid mixtures of polymers and nanoparticles.[88,90–92] Luminescent wood was prepared using quantum dots (QDs) dispersed in methyl methacrylate (MMA) monomer/oligomer liquids followed by polymerization,[88] as shown in Figure 7.
Photoluminescence mapping showed uniform distribution of emission points (Figure 7b). The emission and absorption spectra are presented (Figure 7c) and successful shift in wavelengths is confirmed. It is concluded that the QDs are well dispersed also inside TW since the quantum yield is high (36%, same as starting QD-MMA liquid). A later study[91] used similar preparation method with γ-Fe2O3@YVO4:Eu3+ nanoparticles. Yu et al. presented modification for a different purpose, namely heat-shielding transparent wood[90] considered for windows, based on CsxWO3 nanoparticles with near infrared (NIR) absorption properties.
Preparation of modified transparent wood can also be based on impregnation of the active compound, followed by monomer impregnation and polymerization. Vasileva et al.[89] prepared wood to investigate the potential for wave-guiding and a “wood laser.” An organic dye solution was used to impregnate wood. MMA monomer/oligomer impregnation and polymerization were then carried out, and indeed, lasing emission was confirmed. Subjected to pump light, wood tracheids (fibers) act as optical resonators and this results in lasing action for the wood material. The nanoparticle or molecular dye content

is usually low (less than 1 wt%), since optical transmittance is reduced at higher content. For building applications, largerscale structures are needed. For this reason, future challenges include increased thickness and specimen size of transparent wood with controllable transmittance and haze.
Before discussing wood surfaces, it should be pointed out that apart from transparent wood, another research area under rapid development is wood-based devices in general.[94] This area includes supercapacitors and anisotropic conductors[95] and solar steam generation devices.[96] The latter example is particularly interesting since it is bioinspired in the sense that the liquid transport function in wood is utilized.

sections.heading: 5.4. Wood Surface Utilization and Functionalization
sections.text:
There is a long tradition and wide expertise in wood surface treatments, since wood when not anymore shielded by the bark requires protection in most engineering wood applications. UV irradiation, water, and microorganisms are the main drivers of surface deterioration, resulting in color changes, cracks, and degradation.[9] Wood surface treatments for weathering protection are commonly conducted with synthetic polymer coatings containing UV absorbers (e.g., nanoparticles)[97] or hindered amine light stabilizers[98] as well as various waxes.[99] These treatments lead to a good protection, but the long-term stability remains a problem as a protective polymer coating will be degraded as well by UV irradiation. In recent years, several approaches were undertaken to decorate the wood surface, in particular with metal oxide coatings, which can be controlled at the nanostructural level.[100] When building a dense coating such treatments can form a thin fully inorganic UV protection layer. Due to the high nanostructural control, it is possible to grow different structures on the surface, such as rods with different aspect ratios or platelet structures.[101]
Several of these approaches were inspired by the fundamental studies on the lotus effect and related technical applications[102] as well as Nepenthes Pitcher plants, which were used as a natural role model for the development of slippery liquid-infused porous surfaces (SLIPS).[103] Since the bioinspired combination of nano- and micro patterning has been shown to be beneficial for several surface functionalization treatments, wood may serve as an ideal substrate since it already provides a microstructured surface pattern. In this regard, one may even profit from specific wood features, for instance in
terms of the alternating microstructural patterns of earlywood and latewood. However, wood is also a challenging substrate for any kind of surface treatment, because of its chemical and structural inhomogeneity and the fact that the surface undergoes dimensional changes upon common fluctuations in relative humidity, which results in stresses and strains, and eventually cracks of the coating and/or the wood at its surface. Recent work on establishing LbL coatings on the wood surface have shown that a wood surface functionalization by polyelectrolytes is possible, but that the surface inhomogeneity leads to too

long washing and dipping times, in order to establish a thin coating with high nanostructural control.[104] Nevertheless, in a few studies, wood surfaces were functionalized by the LbL technique to establish a thin coating for UV protection or hydrophobic properties.[105] The specific surface pattern of wood can also be utilized when establishing new properties on the surface.
Another option is to utilize the outer and inner surface of wood as a biobased and easy scalable filter for oil water separation or for waste water treatments (see Figure 8). Boutilier et al. tested the capability of conifer wood to be used as a filter for the removal of bacteria from drinking water. They could show that even without any wood modification or functionalization the porous wood structure could be used to filter out bacteria with a rejection rate beyond 99.9%.[106] On that basis, conifer wood specimens may find application in pressuredriven filtration devices in developing countries as a cheap and biodegradable alternative to synthetic membranes. In a study on using wood disks for oil–water separation, Vidiella del Blanco et al showed, that likewise for drinking water filtration, just the use of the unmodified wood structure can lead to a sufficient efficiency. This is because wood is superoleophobic as long it is kept in a fully water-saturated state, which allows for separating water from oil with an exclusion rate beyond 99%.[107] The system is less sophisticated than nanocellulose-based superhydrophobic and oleophilic sponges,[11] but the wood is much cheaper and easy scalable to reach application-relevant dimensions. Upon functionalization of the inner wood surface an even broader application of the wood filter systems can be envisaged. Chen et al. decorated the inner surface of wood with palladium nanoparticles and could show a high efficiency of such wood membranes in waste water treatments, which was exemplarily demonstrated by the removal of methylene blue from an aqueous solution flowing through the functionalized wood structure.[58] These examples of recent research works illustrate that the structural optimization of wood in the living tree toward water transport and mechanical stability can be utilized for various separation approaches, which have the strong advantage to be easily scalable for technical applications.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and Outlook
sections.text:
The emerging field of advanced wood functionalization, including molecular and nanoscales, is still at an exploratory stage and will need further advancement. A key challenge, initially for research but eventually also for industrial technologies, is to improve nanostructural control of the modified and functionalized wood cell wall. This includes control of chemical and physical processes in the confined pore space of the cell wall, as well as control of the final distribution of material components. An important characteristic of the present approach is that the cell wall nanostructure is preserved and functional, and contributes to structural and load-bearing properties. New functionalities then become highly attractive, since they can be added to the original characteristics of wood.
Research toward a wood nanotechnology vision does on one hand need realistic long-term goals in terms of large-scale
applications, such as functional coatings and translucent panels. On the other hand, wood nanotechnology research needs to be exploratory in nature. This is intrinsic to the general area of nanomaterials, since many small-scale phenomena are poorly understood. For instance, in preparation of bioinspired wood–mineral hybrids, it will be important to control nucleation sites in the nanocompartments of the cell wall. This level of control is a prerequisite in order to approach the nanostructural sophistication of the biological role models. The target for a functional wood composite should be a specific property profile, which depends on nanostructure but also on structural organization at higher hierarchical levels. This can be controlled by selection of wood species, relative density, lamination strategies, and shaping operations.
It is apparent that we are in the early stages of functional wood materials research. For instance, the first attempts to make wood electrically conductive are not very successful in terms of electrical performance. Although the work is well motivated form a research point-of-view, this example illustrates the challenges to replace existing materials with electrically functional wood. A key will be to process the material in such a way that the deposition of functional components (e.g., conducting polymers), is very precise yet feasible to be carried out on large scale. Processes in the living tree can provide inspiration, as suggested by the lignification and heartwood sections in the present report.
Tree bioengineering is another exciting prospect. This includes transgenic trees where the growing tree shows altered characteristics, for instance in terms of cell wall composition or wood polymer structures or distribution. It is possible to use tree bioengineering as a pretreatment step prior to the functionalization, in order to widen the possibilities for modification. Microorganisms represent another bioengineering opportunity. Fungi are often considered in the context of wood degradation, but they can also be utilized to specifically degrade the wood in a controlled way. Fungi or enzyme systems can for instance be used to modify or open the wood structure and facilitate further functionalization treatments.[108] For genetic modification of trees, a common aim is to reduce lignin content or ease lignin degradation for the purpose of pulp and biofuel production.[44,109] Therefore, a merger between the rapidly growing fields of tree bioengineering and wood materials science could further increase the functionalization potentials.[52]
Bioinspired wood functionalization will make it possible to design new types of functional wood–inorganic hybrids and wood–polymer composites, where nanoscale structural control is combined with the existing hierarchical structure of the wood template. Exceptional material property combinations are possible where the intrinsically low density and high stiffness characteristics of wood are combined with new functionalities. Those hybrid materials have the potential to revolutionize timber engineering in modern sustainable construction. There are several unique features of wood scaffolds, which can be exploited. For instance, the anisotropy of the wood structure can be used to develop multiscale composites with tailored directionality in electric conductance, thermal conductance, or magnetic properties. The native water transport channels in wood can be used for liquid flow or thermal energy storage purposes. The insertion of responsive polymers in smaller scale

wood-based structures can lead to functional materials for use in biomedicine and water management. Smart wood materials can be designed for use as sensors, actuators as well as stimuliresponsive devices reacting to changes in relative humidity.[110] Such advanced engineered wood materials can meet the challenge in the building sector to move toward sustainable construction, and at the same time implement smartness and multiple functions into building materials for high living comfort.[111] Furthermore, these materials could also meet the requirements of limited needs for inspection and performance regulation. Here, the wood structure is advantageous, since targeted functionalities can be directly embedded at fine scale within the wood body.
To fulfill these visions of the current exploratory phase, we need better control of the fundamental processes and new knowledge from bioinspired processing attempts. There is also a need for research focused on technical realization and implementation, using simplified reaction condition, and green chemistry approaches. One aspect that needs to be considered when applying nanotechnological tools to optimize and functionalize the wood material is the impact of these treatments on the sustainability and recyclability of the obtained hybrids and composites. While the biobased origin is helpful in the context of sustainability, challenges remain with respect to chemical treatments and polymer modification. In a longer-term perspective, green chemistry is required and monomers need to be biobased and inorganic components should be ecofriendly and nontoxic. Moreover, at the end of the lifecycle a separation or energetic utilization should be possible without difficulties. For most of the mineralization treatments, these targets are almost accomplished, but they are at least developed for in situ polymerization techniques of the wood cell wall. Developments toward new “green solvents” or biobased polymers will be important steps to not spoil the sustainable nature of wood by a functionalization treatment. For polymer-modified materials, recycling schemes where wood is downgraded to fibers for biocomposites are feasible. Naturally occurring inorganics are compatible with similar schemes whereas other inorganics considered for large-scale use need specific analyses.
With respect to large-scale fabrication of functionalized wood materials, the wooden scaffolds are not only widely available in the form of large tree structures, but the infrastructure for harvesting and processing already exists and the material cost is very low. There are, however, two crucial challenges for large-scale applications of nanotechnology in timber construction. First, since the modifying compounds have to diffuse into the complex wood structure, it may not be economical to fully treat very large structures, since full nanostructural control and targeted distribution of the modifying agents is difficult to achieve in a large volume. Second, macroscopic wood defects and changes in fiber grain direction etc. are not acceptable for materials where the nanostructure is painstakingly modified. A possible solution is to use wood veneer, which is also suitable as a research material substrate. Veneer is technically relevant, due to the use in plywood laminates and large beam structures laminated veneer lumber. Due to the low thickness, diffusion distances are short, and veneer can be readily functionalized by nanotechnology methods. It is thus feasible to assemble
functionalized veneer into larger structures, and also to use veneer as functional surface layers. Although the presented wood nanotechnology approaches are at an early stage, the scientific field offers rich possibilities for creative and multidisciplinary materials research, combined with the potential for large-scale applications.
